title: Brussels plans to put the squeeze on commuters
text:
Brussels wants to charge drivers for entering the city — a step that's likely to inflame relations between the country's fractious nationalities.

The capital’s new Mobility Minister Elke Van Den Brandt announced Wednesday that the Brussels regional government will roll out a road tolling system by the end of 2024. Under the plan, people driving into Brussels would have to pay a toll, with higher charges for those arriving in peak traffic or in more polluting vehicles.

“Everyone who regularly comes to Brussels knows how bad the congestion is,” Van Den Brandt told Flemish radio. “Everyone who lives or works or visits knows the air quality is very bad, and that we really have to respond to that. The smart kilometer charge provides an answer.”

But the Green Party minister's plan exacerbates tensions between Brussels, Flanders and Wallonia. That's because the toll is tied to cutting other road use taxes to compensate drivers. People from regions not taking part in the scheme would still have to pay the charge when driving into Brussels, but wouldn't get a tax cut.

“I’m assuming that if Flanders joins the kilometer charge, they’ll lower a number of taxes at the same time in order to make sure that it has an impact on traffic jams, the quality of life and air quality first and foremost ... and to guarantee that the system is fair as well,” Van Den Brandt said.

“A kilometer charge can be a part of the solution on the condition that it's not a tax hike” — Ben Weyts, Flemish transport minister

The original idea was for the whole country to agree to the system. The Brussels region's governing parties agreed in a July coalition deal to try to “clinch a cooperation agreement between the regions with a view to introduce a smart kilometer charge for light vehicles.”

Political traffic jams

But that's run into trouble because neither Flanders nor Wallonia have been able to cobble together a government since May's election.

Van Den Brandt maintains that the Brussels government still wants a broader agreement. “What we’re hoping is that we can still reach an agreement with Flanders — because the government is still in the making,” she said.

But Brussels’ decision to go it alone if necessary has prompted angry reactions from legislators.

“There is no Flemish or Walloon government yet at this time. Discussion is impossible,” said Cieltje Van Achter, who leads the Flemish nationalist party the New Flemish Alliance (N-VA) in the Brussels parliament. “What signal is the Brussels government trying to send with this show of force?”

Her fellow N-VA party member, former Migration Secretary Theo Francken, called — presumably jokingly — for retaliatory tolls in the Flemish region that surrounds Brussels in a series of tweets, proposing a “Zaventem charge,” a “Sonian Forest tax” and a “Brabant toll.”

Even if Flanders and Wallonia agree on coalition governments, the regions are still unlikely to agree a common approach on road charging anytime soon. While Flanders and Brussels were mulling a common kilometer charge that would increase levies in peak traffic, the previous Wallonian government advocated a different flat-rate vignette system.

Walloon Transport Minister Carlo Di Antonio has said it would be “difficult to grasp” having two separate road charging systems in one country.

Outgoing Flemish Transport Minister Ben Weyts, with the N-VA, called the Walloon idea a “stupid charge that doesn’t steer traffic.”

Weyts shelved Flanders’ own long-standing, but rather vague, plans to introduce a charge in the run-up to the May election, after the far-right Vlaams Belang party’s campaign successfully branded it as “tax bullying.”

“A kilometer charge can be a part of the solution on the condition that it's not a tax hike,” Weyts said, defending his decision.

Coalition friction

The political fight over the road charge in Flanders makes it very difficult for the N-VA to shift position once more.

But with negotiations on a government for Flanders still ongoing, and the region’s Christian Democrats reportedly still in favor of a toll, Van Den Brandt hasn’t given up hope that Flanders will eventually back a road charge.

Van Den Brandt's plan could run into opposition in the capital's regional parliament. With its first plenary meeting scheduled for mid-September, lawmakers haven't debated the new government's coalition deal yet — let alone a plan for a toll.

The idea also hasn't got unanimous backing from her fellow ministers.

“As long as the Flemish and Walloon governments haven’t been formed, and as long as there haven’t been any consultations, all declarations by members of the Brussels government about this [subject] are premature,” Brussels Finance Minister Sven Gatz, of the Flemish Liberal party, told Knack.
description: It puts pressure on Flanders and Wallonia to join in if they want to protect their drivers from road charges.
